' "[2410-the good lord] Perhaps [the good Lord]2410-the good lord , who was sorry for [Mary]387-mary and [Martha]134-pat , may be sorry for [her]2409-the desolate child too . Perhaps , after all , [[her]2409-the desolate child boy]4628-her boy is well rid of troublesome breath — well rid of [his]4628-her boy cares , and [[his]4628-her boy farm]2412-his farm , and [[his]4628-her boy useless loving sister]2413-his useless loving sister ! Perhaps [she]2409-the desolate child is falsely fond to desire [him]4628-her boy again — to be so famished for one sight more of [his]4628-her boy grey laughing eyes , of [his]4628-her boy smooth stripling face ! Beyond [her]2409-the desolate child sight , [he]4628-her boy may be in the fruition of extremest good — in the sweet shade , beneath pleasant - fruited trees , beside [great cool rivers]2414-great cool rivers . Would [she]2409-the desolate child tear [him]4628-her boy back again thence to toil in the broiling sun , because , so toiling , [he]4628-her boy would be in [her]2409-the desolate child sight ? " If love were kind , why should [we]5135-we doubtThat holy death were kinder ? "[2409-the desolate child] The night falls fast ; [she]2409-the desolate child can scarcely any longer distinguish the clear , new black letters on the cross . Lights are twinkling from [the village alehouse]2415-the village alehouse ; [the forge]1691-the forge shines like a great dull - red jewel in the surrounding grey ; laughing voices of [boisterous men]2417-boisterous men are wafted unseemly amongst the graves . Shuddering at the sound , [she]2409-the desolate child raises [herself]2409-the desolate child up quickly ; then , stooping again , kisses yet once more the wet red earth that is now closest neighbour to [[her]2409-the desolate child brother]644-her brother , and sobbing " Good - bye , [[my]2409-the desolate child boy]832-my boy , good - bye!—God bless [you]832-my boy , [Jack]146-jack ! "[2409-the desolate child] gathers [her]2409-the desolate child dusky cloak about [her]2409-the desolate child slight shivering figure , and passes away through the darkness . IT has snowed all day ; an immense white monotony is over all [the land]3431-the land . The clouds that piled themselves in sulky threatening last night behind [the Welsh hills]2420-the welsh hills , and [many others like [them]2420-the welsh hills]2421-many others like them , have to - day fulfilled [their]2420-the welsh hills threats , and have been , through all the daylight hours , emptying [their]2420-the welsh hills flaky load on [the patient earth]2422-the patient earth . It is as if a huge white bird had been shaking [his]644-her brother pinions somewhere , high up in the air — shaking down millions of little down feathers . Rain always seems in earnest , snow in play — with such delicate leisureliness does it saunter down . [The rushing train]2423-the rushing train , that bears [Esther]148-esther to [her]148-esther new distant life , is topped like any twelfth - night cake ; so are [the wayside stations]2424-the wayside stations ; so are [the houses in [the smoky towns]2426-the smoky towns]2425-the houses in the smoky towns ; so are [the men]3783-the men , sparsely walking about on [the country roads]2428-the country roads ; so are [the engine drivers]2429-the engine drivers and [stokers]2430-stokers ; so are the sheep in [the fields]2431-the fields . [Miss Craven]164-st. john has been sitting all day long in the narrow enceinte of [a railway carriage]2432-a railway carriage , between the two close - shut , snow - blinded windows — sitting opposite [a courteous warrior , who , travelling with all the luxuriousness which [his]2433-a courteous warrior , who , travelling with all the luxuriousness which his sex sex]2433-a courteous warrior , who , travelling with all the luxuriousness which his sex think indispensable , is magnanimous enough to share [his]2433-a courteous warrior , who , travelling with all the luxuriousness which his sex buffalo - robe and foot - warmer with [her]164-st. john . A téte - à - téte of so many consecutive hours with [a man]3402-a man would , under any other circumstances than a railway journey , have produced an intimacy that would last a life - time ; but now , all the result of it is a couple of bows on [the platform at [Paddington]99-paddington]2435-the platform at paddington — a look of interested curiosity after [[his]2433-a courteous warrior , who , travelling with all the luxuriousness which his sex late companion]2436-his late companion 's retreating figure , as [she]164-st. john hurries [herself]164-st. john and [[her]164-st. john small properties]2437-her small properties into [a filthy four - wheeler]2438-a filthy four - wheeler , on the part of [the warrior]2439-the warrior , and total oblivion on the part of [Esther]148-esther . Since that time [she]164-st. john has traversed [London]16-london in [[her]164-st. john dilapidated shambling growler]2440-her dilapidated shambling growler , [she]164-st. john has had awful misgiving that [the " cabby]5137-the " cabby , "[5137-the " cabby] with the villany that [all women]1476-all women ascribe to all " [cabbies]5138-cabbies , "[5137-the " cabby] is purposely taking [her]164-st. john in a wrong direction — is bearing [her]164-st. john away to [some dark , policeless slum]2442-some dark , policeless slum , there to be robbed and murdered . [She]164-st. john has reflected , with cold shivers of terror , as to what would be the wisest course to pursue , supposing such to be the case . Should [she]164-st. john look silently out of window till [she]164-st. john caught sight of the friendly helmet and tight frock - coat of some delivering " [Bobby]190-bob , "[164-st. john] and then scream ? Should [she]164-st. john open the door and jump out on the snowy pavement ? While still undecided , [[her]164-st. john cab]2443-her cab stops , and — all mean [back - streets]2444-back - streets and sorry short - cuts being safely passed - deposits [her]164-st. john and [her]164-st. john box , bag , and umbrella , beneath the Shoreditch lamps and among [the Shoreditch porters]2445-the shoreditch porters . Then an hour 's waiting in [the crowded general waiting - room]2446-the crowded general waiting - room , where all the chairs are occupied by [fat men]2447-fat men , [none of whom make a movement towards vacating theirs]2448-none of whom make a movement towards vacating theirs in favour of [the slender weary woman]2449-the slender weary woman , who , with crape veil thrown back from [her]2449-the slender weary woman sad child - face , is holding [her]2449-the slender weary woman little numb hands over the fire , trying vainly to bring them back to life . Then [more train]2450-more train ; then a three - miles ' drive in a fly , up [hill and down dale]2451-hill and down dale , along [snowy country lanes]2452-snowy country lanes . And now [her]164-st. john journey is ended : [the fly]2453-the fly has stopped at the door of a great , vague , snow - whitened bulk , that [she]164-st. john takes upon trust as [Blessington Court]97-blessington court . [The driver]2454-the driver , having rung the bell , now stands banging [his]2454-the driver arms , each one against the opposite shoulder , in the rough endeavour to restore circulation . [The servants]4284-the servants are too comfortable — [the butler]1089-the butler over [his]1089-the butler mulled port in [[the housekeeper]2457-the housekeeper 's room]2458-the housekeeper 's room , and [the footmen]2459-the footmen over [their]2459-the footmen mulled beer in [[the servants]4284-the servants ' hall]2461-the servants ' hall — to be in any hurry to attend to the summons . At length , after five minutes ' waiting , a sound of withdrawing bolts and turning keys makes itself heard ; the heavy door swings inward , and [a footman]2346-a footman appears in the aperture , blinking disgustedly at the snow , which drives full into [his]2346-a footman eyes . [Esther]148-esther immediately descends , and enters with the abrupt haste characteristic of extreme nervousness . " Will [you]3894-the man pay [him]3894-the man , please ? "[148-esther] [she]148-esther says , with a certain flurry of manner , to [the servant]800-the servant . " [I]148-esther — [I]148-esther do n't know how much [I]148-esther ought to give [him]3894-the man — how many miles it is . "[148-esther] While [the man]3894-the man complies with [her]148-esther request , [she]148-esther stands in [the huge stone - floored hall , lit only by firelight]2465-the huge stone - floored hall , lit only by firelight , shivering with cold and fear . [She]148-esther peers up at the ceiling — of which , by - the - bye , there is none , as [the hall]658-the hall runs up to the top of [the house]687-the house ; at the walls , from which great life - size figures , dimly naked , glimmer uncomfortably cold . Anxious doubts assail [her]148-esther as to whether there are any rules of which [she]148-esther is ignorant for [a " companion]5139-a " companion 's "[2468-they] behaviour and deportment ; [she]148-esther is not aware that [she]148-esther has ever seen one of those curious animals hitherto in the course of [her]148-esther life . Ought [they]2468-they to make a reverence on entering [a room]2469-a room ? Ought [they]2468-they to say " [Sir]3823-sir "[2468-they] or " Ma'am "[2468-they] to whoever [they]2468-they address ? Ought [they]2468-they to laugh at [everybody]3709-everybody 's jokes?—not sit down unless given leave so to do , and not speak unless spoken to ? So wondering , [she]148-esther tremblingly follows [the footman]2286-the footman as [he]2286-the footman opens the door of [an adjoining apartment]2472-an adjoining apartment , and , announcing " [Miss Craven]164-st. john , "[2286-the footman] retires joyfully to the society of [his]2286-the footman compeers and [his]2286-the footman beer . [The apartment in which [Esther]148-esther is thus left stranded]2473-the apartment in which esther is thus left stranded is as large as [the hall that [she]148-esther has just quitted]2474-the hall that she has just quitted . [It]2475-it seems to [her]148-esther oppressively immense — quite a long walk from the door to [the inhabited portion]2476-the inhabited portion . A very big roasting fire burns on the hearth : and right in front of [it]2477-it , in the very glare of its hot red eyes , sits [a very old man]2478-a very old man , doubled together in an armchair — one hand in [his]2478-a very old man breast , and [his]2478-a very old man aged head sunk upon it , apparently fast asleep . [An old lady , wrapped up in a shawl]2479-an old lady , wrapped up in a shawl , reposes in another easy - chair , with [her]2479-an old lady , wrapped up in a shawl eyes likewise closed . A lamp with a green shade burns faintly on a centre table , and beyond lamp and table sits [a third person]4238-a third person , hidden by the lamp - shade from [Esther]148-esther 's eyes . " Are [they]5141-they all asleep ? "[2481-the poor girl] thinks [the poor girl]2481-the poor girl , advancing with gentle , hesitating steps . " [They]5141-they seem to be . "[437-mrs. blessington] Weak from inanition , and with limbs cramped by long remaining in one position , [Esther]148-esther follows [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington up low flights of [uncarpeted stone stairs]2493-uncarpeted stone stairs , through [draughty twisting passages]2494-draughty twisting passages , along [a broad bare gallery]2495-a broad bare gallery , down [more passages]2496-more passages , and then into [a huge gloomy , mouldy room]2497-a huge gloomy , mouldy room — frosty , yet cold , despite the fire burning briskly on the old- fashioned - hobbed grate ; a vast dark four - poster , hung with ginger - coloured moreen ; a couch that looks highly suitable for lying - in - state on ; an old - fashioned screen , covered with caricatures of [Fox]439-fox , [Burke]440-burke , [the Regent]2498-the regent , and [Queen Caroline]441-queen caroline ; and on the walls a highly valuable and curious tapestry , which waves pleasantly in the bitter wind that enters freely beneath the ill - fitting old door , giving an air of galvanic motion and false life to [the ill - looking Cupids]2499-the ill - looking cupids , green with age , that play hide - and - seek amongst vases , broken pillars and wormy blue trees . " [You]5161-you have plenty of [room]5162-room , [you]5161-you see , "[258-miss blessington] says [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington , with a curve of [her]258-miss blessington suave lips , as [she]258-miss blessington lights the candles on the dressing - table , which , instead of being pink petticoated , white - muslined deal , is bare sturdy oak , with millions of little useless drawers and pigeon - holes in it . " [We]5166-we will hope that [you]256-constance will not make the experiment , "[148-esther] [she]148-esther answers , with a cold smile , and so goes . [I]0-i THINK that [people]3426-people 's value , or want of value , is seldom [their]3426-people own : it belongs rather to the circumstances that surround [them]3426-people — to attributes foreign to [themselves]3426-people — outside of [them]3426-people . Had [Robinson Crusoe]442-robinson crusoe , while walking down [Bond Street]101-bond street in flowing wig and lace ruffles , first met [[his]442-robinson crusoe man]2505-his man Friday , [he]442-robinson crusoe might have tossed [him]2505-his man sixpence to avoid [his]442-robinson crusoe importunities ; but would hardly have taken [him]2505-his man into intimate friendship — would hardly even have admitted [him]2505-his man as [a man]3402-a man and [a brother]3525-a brother . Among [the blind the one - eyed]2508-the blind the one - eyed is [king]3778-king , and among [a crowd of total strangers]2510-a crowd of total strangers [an acquaintance]2511-an acquaintance rises into [a friend]1386-a friend . [Lonely Esther]148-esther is half - inclined to effect this metamorphosis in the case of [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington . The mere fact of having eaten , drank , and slept for a considerable period under the same roof with [her]148-esther — the bare fact of having lived with and disliked [her]148-esther during a whole month and more — was enough recommendation in [a house not one of whose inmates had [she]148-esther ever beheld before]2513-a house not one of whose inmates had she ever beheld before . Almost as [a friend]1386-a friend has [she]148-esther greeted [her]148-esther this morning . With admiration most unfeigned , though made a little bitter by mental comparison with [her]148-esther own dimmed , grief - blighted beauty , has [she]148-esther regarded [the stately woman]2515-the stately woman , the splendid animal , sleek and white as a sacred Egyptian cow ; the brilliancy of whose pale , bright hair , and the perfect smoothness of [her]148-esther great satin throat , are heightened by the sober richness of [her]148-esther creaseless black velvet dress . Voluptuous , yet cold , the passions that [her]148-esther splendid physique provoke are chilled to death by the passionless stupor of [her]148-esther soul . [I]0-i am not at all sure that impassioned ugliness — supposing the ugliness to be moderate , and the passion immoderate — has not more attraction for the generality of [men]595-men than iced beauty . [Esther]148-esther 's warmth is thrown away ; [she]148-esther might as well expect that the " [Venus de Medici]444-venus de medici "[148-esther] would return the pressure of warm clinging fingers with [her]148-esther freezing , sculptured hand . " [I]164-st. john was so glad to find [you]148-esther here last night : it was so pleasant to see a face [one]559-one knew , "[164-st. john] [Miss Craven]164-st. john says , with the rash credulity of youth unexpectant of snubs . [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington looks slightly surprised . " Tha — anks ; it is very good of [you]148-esther to say so , [I]258-miss blessington am sure , "[258-miss blessington] [she]258-miss blessington answers , rather drawlingly , and with a small , cold smile that would repress demonstrations much more violent than any that [Esther]148-esther had meditated . It is difficult always to remember that [one]559-one is a " companion "[559-one] [The Blessington dining - room]2518-the blessington dining - room is , like [the other reception - rooms]2519-the other reception - rooms , huge and very nobly proportioned . Did [we]2520-we not know that [our]2520-we seventeenth and eighteenth century ancestors were not [giants]2521-giants , [we]2520-we should be prone to imagine that it must have been a race of Anakims that required such great wide spaces to sup , and sip chocolate , and play at omnbre in . The furniture is in its dotage ; it has , figuratively speaking , like [its owners]2522-its owners , lost hair and teeth , and all unnecessary etceteras ; it is reduced to the bare elements of existence . Three tall windows look out upon [a flat lawn]2523-a flat lawn , and in the middle of [this lawn]2524-this lawn , exactly opposite [Esther]148-esther 's eyes , as [she]148-esther sits at breakfast , is an unique and chaste piece of statuary , entitled " The Rape of [the Sabines]445-the sabines . "[446-roman] The space afforded by the stone pediment is necessarily limited , and consequently [Roman]446-roman and [Sabines]445-the sabines , [gentlemen]4648-gentlemen and [lady]2526-lady , are all piled one a - top of another in such inextricable confusion as to demand a good quarter of an hour 's close observation to determine which of the muscular writhing legs belong to [the Roman ravisher]2527-the roman ravisher and which to [the injured Sabine husband]2528-the injured sabine husband . As [the sculptor]2529-the sculptor has given none of [his]2529-the sculptor protégées any clothing , the snow has been kind enough to throw a modest white mantle over [them]2530-them all . " Reading aloud to [[my]256-constance uncle]5170-my uncle is very fatiguing , "[256-constance] replies [Constance]256-constance , cheeringly : " [one]559-one has to sustain [one]559-one 's voice at a pitch several octaves higher than the natural one . " [I]1100-the other daresay it wo n't affect [mine]1100-the other , "[1100-the other] rejoins [the other]1100-the other rather drily . There is a pause . " [I]148-esther hope , "[148-esther] says [Esther]148-esther , presently , trusting to the obtuseness of [[her]148-esther companion]3572-her companion 's perceptions not to discover the flagrant hypocrisy of the question—"I hope that [Sir Thomas]238-sir thomas was quite well when [you]3572-her companion left [Felton]44-felton ? "[148-esther] " Quite — thanks . "[148-esther] " And [Lady Gerard]239-lady gerard ? "[148-esther] " Yes — thanks . "[148-esther] " And — and "[148-esther] ( bending down [her]148-esther head in the vain endeavour to screen the red blush that the frosty sun , flaming in through the window opposite , makes obtrusively evident)—and [Mr. Gerard]247-mr. gerard ? " "[247-mr. gerard] [He]247-mr. gerard is very well — thanks , " replies [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington , with the conscious smile that had formerly exasperated [Esther]148-esther , and with an emphasis not common with [her]148-esther . [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington does not usually employ emphasis : it is mezzoceto , as is enthusiasm of which it is [the exponent]5175-the exponent . Half an hour later [Esther]148-esther is sitting beside [the old squire]5153-the old squire , as close as possible to [his]5153-the old squire best ear , brandishing the Times ' giant squares in [her]148-esther unaccustomed hand . [The old squire]5153-the old squire is [a superb wreck]5178-a superb wreck . [Spiteful Time]447-spiteful time is fond of removing the landmarks that [youth]615-youth sets upon [our]5180-our faces ; is fond of changing great , clear , almond eyes into little damp jellies — sweet moist pursemouths into dry bags of wrinkles ; but it is a task beyond even [his]5153-the old squire power to destroy the shape of that grand old bent head — to deface the outlines of that thin - nostriled , patrician nose . "[247-mr. gerard] What shall [I]0-i read first ? " asks [the young girl]3585-the young girl , timidly , but enunciating each syllable with painstaking slowness and clearness . "[0-i] The State of [the Funds]2536-the funds , " replies [the old gentleman]5182-the old gentleman , promptly , thrusting [his]5182-the old gentleman hand into [his]5182-the old gentleman breast , and closing [his]5182-the old gentleman eyes , in [his]5182-the old gentleman favourite attitude . [Esther]148-esther has not the most distant idea where the "[0-i] State of [the Funds]2536-the funds " lives : [she]148-esther turns the huge sheets topsy - turvy — inside out , outside in — in the vain search for [their]2536-the funds habitat , making , meanwhile , the most unjustifiable aggressive rustling and crackling , which [she]148-esther presumptuously trusts to [his]5182-the old gentleman deafness not to hear . "[0-i] Do n't make such an infernal crackling , [[my]0-i dear]804-my dear ! " [he]5182-the old gentleman says presently , with some pettishness . "[0-i] [I]0-i thought [you]0-i could not hear , " [she]148-esther unwisely answers , trembling . "[0-i] [God]435-god bless [my]0-i soul , [child]3639-child ! [The dead]2540-the dead would have heard the noise [you]3639-child were making , " [he]5182-the old gentleman rejoins , snappishly . Having at length mastered the fact that the "[2540-the dead] State of the Funds " comes under the head of "[2540-the dead] Money Market and City Intelligence , " [Esther]148-esther gives the desired information . Then follows [a leader]5183-a leader : "[2540-the dead] The position of American politics is at this moment peculiarly perplexing and anomalous ; so perplexing that even [those English observers who , like [ourselves]2542-ourselves , have given a careful and constant attention to the course of the Transatlantic movement since the first appearance of [Secession]448-secession]2541-those english observers who , like ourselves , have given a careful and constant attention to the course of the transatlantic movement since the first appearance of secession , can hardly pretend clearly to understand — " "[435-god] Pretend clearly to what ? For [God]435-god 's sake do n't gabble so ! " "[435-god] Can — hardly — pretend — clearly — to — understand — the — full — meaning — of — the — situation,—and — must — feel — that — it — would — be — " "[435-god] Is there no medium , may [I]0-i ask , between gabbling and drawling ? " "[0-i] And must feel that it would be rash to express a confident opinion thereupon . " [Esther]148-esther now proceeds for a considerable period unchecked — gradually and unconsciously relapsing into the brisk gallop so dear to youth when engaged upon a subject that does not interest it . Suddenly a deep slumberous breath , drawn close to [her]148-esther ear , makes [her]148-esther aware that [[her]148-esther hearer]5184-her hearer has lapsed into sleep . "[0-i] [I]0-i have read [him]2543-his to sleep , " [she]0-i says to [herself]0-i , with a sort of triumphant feeling at [her]0-i own prowess , taking furtive glances at the wrinkled profile , sunk , in perfect imbecility of slumber , on [his]2543-his breast . Not feeling any particular personal interest in the effect of Secession upon American politics , [she]0-i stops , and gazes vacantly out of window at the "[0-i] Rape of [the Sabines]445-the sabines . " But the cessation of the sweet monotony that lulled [him]2543-his , arouses [the old man]2484-the old man . "[0-i] Go on — go on ! " [he]2543-his cries , fussily , lifting [his]2543-his head and opening [his]2543-his dim eyes . "[0-i] What are [you]0-i stopping for ? Read that paragraph over again ; [you]0-i read it so fast that [I]0-i could not quite follow the meaning of it . " [She]0-i complies , and so , with dozing and waking , waking and dozing , on one side , reading and stopping , stopping and reading on the other , the little drama plays itself out till nearly luncheon - time . "[0-i] [We]2544-we are going to drive into [Shelford]102-shelford this afternoon ; do [you]0-i feel inclined to come with [us]2544-we , [Constance]256-constance , [[my]0-i dear]804-my dear ? " asks [the old lady]3509-the old lady , as [they]2544-we quit the luncheon - table — [Esther]148-esther dutifully bringing up the rear , with air - cushion , footstool , and couvre - pied . "[256-constance] Not to - day , [aunt]1203-aunt , [I]0-i think — thanks , " answers [Constance]256-constance , with the utmost sweetness ; the "[1203-aunt] Not to - day " seeming to imply that on some future morrow [she]256-constance will gladly avail [herself]256-constance of the invitation to join [[her]256-constance elderly relatives]5187-her elderly relatives in [[their]5187-her elderly relatives triste airing]5188-their triste airing ; but [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington being in [her]258-miss blessington generation [a wise woman]5189-a wise woman , that morrow never comes . [The old family]5190-the old family - coach rolls round [the frosty sweep]5191-the frosty sweep to the door ; two large horses , sleek and fat with over - many oats and over - little work , draw it . "[0-i] The tails of both hung down behind , [Their]2547-their shoes were on [their]2547-their feet . " "[1203-aunt] Give [me]0-i [your]0-i arm , [Miss Craven]164-st. john ; one is very apt to fall this frosty weather , " says [the old lady]3509-the old lady , appearing at the door , transformed , by the aid of numberless cloaks and shawls , and a huge velvet bonnet , date anno domini , into a large and perfectly shapeless bundle . Supported on one side by [Esther]148-esther 's slender arm , and on the other by [the florid and plethoric butler]5193-the florid and plethoric butler , [she]148-esther is hoisted up the three steps into the body of the ancient machine , which is painted invisible green , and hung marvellous high in air . The same course is pursued with [the old gentleman]5182-the old gentleman , who , muffled , comfortered , and scarved up to the tip of [his]5182-the old gentleman venerable nose , follows . Lastly , [the young prop]5195-the young prop steps in , and sits down humbly with [her]5195-the young prop back to the horses — a process which usually ends in making [her]5195-the young prop sick . The windows are shut tight up ; a great hot skin of some wild beast is thrown over [their]2547-their knees ; in that confined atmosphere it emits a strong furry odour , more powerful than agreeable ; striving emulously with it — sometimes mastering it , sometimes mastered by it — is the fusty smell of the cloth lining . [The old people]5196-the old people do not seem to perceive either ; old noses haie less keen scent , old lungs require less air to feed on , than [young ones]4316-young ones . "[164-st. john] Trit - trot , trit - trot , trit - trot , " goes [the old vehicle]5198-the old vehicle along the beaten snow of [the broad turnpike - road]5199-the broad turnpike - road . As [they]2547-their are jogging a little brisklier than usual down a very slight decline , [the old gentleman]5182-the old gentleman speaks — [his]5182-the old gentleman strong , shaky old voice loudly audible above the "[164-st. john] rumble — rumble — rumble , " which , joined to the want of air , is fast making [Esther]148-esther faint and headachy : "[164-st. john] What [the deuce]1310-the deuce does [Ruggles]449-ruggles mean going at such a pace down [these steep hills]2549-these steep hills ? Does [he]1310-the deuce think [he]1310-the deuce is to knock [my]0-i horses ' legs all to pieces for [his]1310-the deuce own amusement ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm sure [I]0-i do n't know , [Mr. Blessington]438-mr. blessington , " answers [the old lady]3509-the old lady , nervously laying hold of the side of [the carriage]3788-the carriage ; "[438-mr. blessington] it is not at all safe this slippery weather ; [I]0-i 'm sure [I]0-i hope the horses are roughed . " "[164-st. john] [Miss Craven]164-st. john , tell [him]1310-the deuce to mind what [he]1310-the deuce is about ; tell [him]1310-the deuce to go slower — much slower , " says [the old gentleman]5182-the old gentleman , in some excitement . [Miss Craven]164-st. john , having with some difficulty lowered the front window , thrusts [her]164-st. john head out of it , and , having taken the opportunity to open mouth and nose and eyes as wide as they will go , to inhale as large a quantity as possible of crisp fresh air , cries : "[1310-the deuce] [Ruggles]449-ruggles ! [Ruggles]449-ruggles ! go slower ! much slower ! " [Ruggles]449-ruggles grins , but complies , and subsides into a solemn walk , which continues until [they]5204-they reach [Shelford]102-shelford . There smug [bareheaded shop - keepers]5205-bareheaded shop - keepers , violet - nosed , scarlet - fingered , standing out in [the cold street]5206-the cold street at the carriage - door , executing with pleased alacrity extensive commissions of half a yard of elastic for [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington — three ounces of red wool for [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington 's knitting — half a dozen blue envelopes for [Mr. Blessington]438-mr. blessington . Then , "[1310-the deuce] trit - trot , jig - jog , " [home]701-home again . Dinner at six : a later hour would be fatal to [his]5182-the old gentleman digestion , [the old gentleman]5182-the old gentleman thinks , then , a nice long evening — long as one of those Veillées du Cháteau , when [Madame la Baronne]450-madame la baronne read aloud some enthralling yet severely moral tale , and [Cassar]451-cassar and [Caroline]441-queen caroline and Pulchérie all sat entranced , unheeding the flight of time , as ticked away by the château clocks . There is only one small lamp in the whole of [the grand old room]5209-the grand old room , and that , in deference to [the old man]2484-the old man 's failing eyes , is hung with so large and deep a green shade , that it is impossible to see to do anything by its light . There is nothing for it but to gape , from seven till ten , at the great battle - pieces hung round the walls — to endeavour to make out , by the aid of the fitful firelight , the singularly clean dead bodies , free apparently from the slightest speck of dust , or stain of blood ; at the red - nostriled chargers , snorting away [their]5211-their ebbing lives with all four legs in the air . At ten o'clock , [James]428-james rung for , to light the candles : then [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington , [her]437-mrs. blessington air - cushion , work - basket , and Shetland shawl , escorted to [[her]437-mrs. blessington room]5212-her room ; two long chapters and several psalms read to [her]437-mrs. blessington ; then a frightened rush along [dark passages and draughty galleries]5213-dark passages and draughty galleries to [the great distant bedroom]5214-the great distant bedroom — to the rats ' multifarious noises ; to the ingenious tunes played by the wind upon the rattling window - frames ; to the ginger - curtained bed and many - folded screen ; to possible sleep , and certain terrors — terrors none the less awful for being totally unreasonable . THIS first day is a sample of [Esther]148-esther 's new life ; the other days were like it — not a jot better , not a jot worse . The same thing happened at the same time each day : no two things ever changed places . It was a life that provided all the necessaries of life — that demanded no hard manual labour , no overworking of the brain . The intellectual faculties that it called into play must have been possessed by [any moderately intelligent seven - years ' child]5215-any moderately intelligent seven - years ' child . [No one]891-no one bullies [Esther]148-esther ; [no one]891-no one oppresses [her]148-esther ; [no one]891-no one troubles [their]891-no one head much about [her]148-esther . So as [she]148-esther performs [her]148-esther monotonous , easy , tiresome little duties towards [them]891-no one , [the old people]5196-the old people have no sort of objection to [her]148-esther enjoying life , if [she]148-esther can . With [the aged]2532-the aged , comfort and happiness are interchangeable terms : continuous warmth of body , pleasant - tasted meats , a profound stagnant quiet around [their]5196-the old people arm - chairs , much sleep — these are [their]5196-the old people summum bonum . [They]5196-the old people have had love , and have outlived it — excitement also , and grief : [they]5196-the old people have outlived all but the elemental instincts that refuse to be outlived . Looking back from the vantage - ground of dotage on the fought battle of life , [they]5196-the old people wonder that [any one]523-any one can long to be in the thick of it . In this life of [Esther]148-esther 's there are no hardships to be borne — none of those sufferings , the enduring of which with self - conscious complacent heroism almost compensates [them]5196-the old people . It has none of the elements of tragedy : there is nothing very noble in bearing with respectable patience the trifling annoyance of making [yourself]5222-yourself hoarse roaring the price of wheat , and the pros and cons of disendowment , into [an old man]5223-an old man 's ear ; there is nothing grand in picking up the countless dropped stitches in [an old woman]819-an old woman 's knitting . In it there is nothing to endure , nothing to enjoy ; it is essentially negative , flat , stale , sterile . It would be all very well if any end were to be seen to it ; if it were not a sort of small Eternity in life ; if there were to be distant holidays to be looked forward to , when the few saved pounds might be poured , with the joyful generosity of [the very poor]5225-the very poor , into [some stricken parent]5226-some stricken parent 's lap — might go to buy boots and shoes for [needy little brothers]5227-needy little brothers and [sisters]3770-sisters . But "[1310-the deuce] Fatherly , motherly , sisterly , brotherlyHome [she]2550-her has none . " All [her]2550-her life seems crowded into the seventeen years behind [her]2550-her ; there seems to be nothing left to happen in the fifty or sixty years ahead . [She]2550-her has nothing to look forward to but huge cycles of newspaper - reading , footstool - carrying , message- running ; of lending all [her]2550-her useful organs of sight and hearing and touch to [others]4701-others ; of keeping for [herself]2550-her only [her]2550-her suffering , aching , empty heart ! "[1310-the deuce] Every succeeding year will steal something away from [her]2550-her beauty . " [People]3426-people pity [her]2550-her now , because [she]2550-her is so young and pretty — not reflecting that the possession of the two best gifts under heaven makes [her]2550-her so much the less worthy a subject for compassion . Twenty years hence , [she]2550-her will probably be [a "[1310-the deuce] companion "]5231-a " companion " still — will be not near so young , nor near so touching , and infinitely more to be pitied . The snow lies long — longer than it generally does at this time of year . Ordinarily the old Cheshire saying holds good : "[1310-the deuce] If there 's ice in October as'll hould a duck , All the rest of the winter'll turn to muck ! " But this October there has been ice enough to hold many ducks ; but yet the rest of the winter shows no signs of , as [the homely]5232-the homely saw phrases it , "[1310-the deuce] turning to muck . " In [the little flower - garden]5233-the little flower - garden , round three sides of which [the ivied buttressed house]5234-the ivied buttressed house is built , only a white heap here , and a white depression there , show where bush or bed were wo nt to be . Over [the fair wide park]5235-the fair wide park , with all [its]5235-the fair wide park mimic hills and [valleys]5236-valleys , copses and spinneys , [God]435-god has laid a great sheet — great as the one that was let down by [its]5234-the ivied buttressed house four corners on [the housetop to the fastidious Apostle]5237-the housetop to the fastidious apostle — a sheet purely , crisply , miserably white . In [the park]3880-the park [Esther]148-esther , in the early gloaming , after the daily drive , so literally a promenade en voiture , takes long walks ; ruins [her]148-esther boots , discolours [her]148-esther petticoats , and makes [her]148-esther crape crimp with snow - water : strolls listless and alone under the old bare trees that have stripped off all [their]5232-the homely clothing — now at the very time that [they]5232-the homely seem to need [them]5232-the homely most ; traces the slender footprints of the famished birds — the little delicate tracks crossing and recrossing one another . And always the leading thought — displaced now and then by lesser thoughts , that flit like travelling swallows through [her]148-esther mind , but ever , ever returning — is , "[1310-the deuce] Where is [Jack]146-jack ? Where has [[my]0-i boy]832-my boy gone to ? Where is [he]146-jack now , at this moment " If [some trusty messenger]5239-some trusty messenger could but come to [her]148-esther , with sure tidings , saying , "[146-jack] It is well with [him]146-jack ! " Has [she]148-esther any reason for believing [him]146-jack to be in [heaven]1042-heaven , beyond the vague confidence that [most people]3703-most people seem to feel that [[their]3703-most people relatives]5242-their relatives must be there , on the principle , [I]146-jack suppose , of [the French Duke , of whom [[his]146-jack kindred]5244-his kindred remarked , that "[146-jack] [God]435-god would certainly think twice ' avant de damner une personne de sa qualité]5243-the french duke , of whom his kindred remarked , that " god would certainly think twice ' avant de damner une personne de sa qualité ! ' " [Jack]146-jack 's death had been most unlike the deaths of the shining Evangelical lights in [Bessy Brandon]202-bessy 's books , whose whole lives had been but trifling prologues to the jubilant drama of [their]5245-their death . [Death]192-death had been to [them]5245-their an ecstasy ; [they]5245-their had died with words of confident rapture on [their]5245-their lips , with strains of welcoming music in [their]5245-their ears : [he]146-jack had departed painfully , sadly , almost dumbly ; no sound of triuphant clarions greeted [him]146-jack from beyond [Death]192-death 's deep ford . Is [he]452-faustus , then , in [hell]5246-hell ? Oh blessed doctrine of cleansing purgatorial pains ! if [our]5247-our faith would but admit of [you]5248-you ! Which of [us]5247-our does not seem to [himself]452-faustus so much too bad for heaven , so much too good for hell ? "[435-god] Let [Faustus]452-faustus live in hell a thousand years , A hundred thousand , and at the last be saved ! " Where is [he]452-faustus , then?—where is [he]452-faustus ? [She]202-bessy takes counsel of [the mute forces of nature]5249-the mute forces of nature — of the clouds , the snows , and the blasts But of what use ? [They]5245-their knew not of [his]452-faustus story ; or , if [they]5245-their did , [they]5245-their were forbidden to tell of it ; silence was laid like a seal upon [their]5245-their lips . It is not in the most edifying books that the grandest sayings are to be found . What can be nobler than this of [Rousseau]351-rousseau 's dying [Julie]408-juliet : "[435-god] Qui s'endort dans le sein d'un père , n'est pas en souci du réveil ? " [The wearier in body]5250-the wearier in body [she]5250-the wearier in body can return from these long , sad rambles , the better pleased is [Esther]148-esther ; for is not weariness [the father of sleep]5251-the father of sleep — sleep , the one impartial thing under [heaven]1042-heaven ; sleep , [the radical]5253-the radical ; sleep , [the leveller]5254-the leveller , that leaves [a king]4395-a king 's arms to embrace [a tinker]5256-a tinker ? But of what use is it to sleep , if in sleep [one hear—"False[435-god] voices]5257-one hear—"false voices , feel the kisses of false mouths , And footless sound of perished feet ? " And worse even than such dream - tortured slumber is fear - tortured waking . Constitutionally timid , a weakened body and broken spirit have made [Esther]148-esther pitiably nervous . Jealousy , remorse , and fear run a dreary race for the palm of extremest suffering ; and [I]435-god am not sure that fear does not win . [The poor child]5258-the poor child suffers the torments of the damned in [[her]5258-the poor child huge hearse - bed]5259-her huge hearse - bed in [the far - off , rat - haunted , ghostly old chamber]5260-the far - off , rat - haunted , ghostly old chamber . [She]5258-the poor child dreads falling asleep , for fear of waking to find the low fire playing antics with [Burke]440-burke 's long nose and spectacles , with [Pitt]453-pitt 's maypole figure on the screen ; flickering over the malignant fleshy Cupids on the wall ; waking to see , looking in upon [her]5258-the poor child through the curtains , [Jack]146-jack 's face — not kind , débonnaire , smiling , as [she]5258-the poor child used to see it in [the study]3754-the study at [home]701-home ( for that could frighten [no one]891-no one ) , but solemn , stiff , with closed eyes and bandaged chin , as [she]5258-the poor child had last seen it . Sometimes [she]5258-the poor child sits up in bed , a cold sweat standing on [her]5258-the poor child brow , as some noise , distincter than usual , sounds through [the room]3629-the room ; "[435-god] thud , thud , " as of some falling object ; an unexplained rustling in [the passage]5265-the passage ; a little clicking in the door - lock — sits up , listening with strained ears , thinking , "[435-god] Can that be rats ? " Momently [she]5258-the poor child expects to see [some crape - masked burglar]5266-some crape - masked burglar enter the door or window . And if [such burglar]5267-such burglar did enter , it would be useless to scream for help ; [she]5258-the poor child is too far off from the rest of [the household]4727-the household to be heard : it would be of no use to ring the bell , for it rings [downstairs]1293-downstairs , miles away , and [everybody]3709-everybody is in bed and asleep [upstairs]3979-upstairs . So [she]5258-the poor child lies quaking — [her]5258-the poor child terror now and then rising to such an uncontrollable pitch that [she]5258-the poor child feels as though , if it lasted a moment longer , [she]5258-the poor child must go mad : listening with intense impatience to the leisurely "[435-god] Tick - tack , tick - tack , tick - tack " of the cuckoo- clock outside ; listening with inexpressible longing to hear [it]5272-it say , "[435-god] Cuckoo , cuckoo , cuckoo , cuckoo ! " four times . At four o'clock [she]5258-the poor child will be safe , [she]5258-the poor child thinks ; at four o'clock cocks begin to crow , [dairymaids]5273-dairymaids to get up , [the bodiless dead]5274-the bodiless dead return to [[their]5274-the bodiless dead churchyard homes]5275-their churchyard homes , night 's unutterable horror to pass . What wonder if , after the agony of such vigils — agony causeless , [you]5276-you will say , unreasonable , but none the less real , none the less acute for that — [she]5258-the poor child comes down in the morning wan , nerveless , with haggard cheeks , and great dark streaks under the unrested beauty of [her]5258-the poor child eyes ? "[435-god] The time is near the birth of [Christ]420-christ the loaf . " "[420-christ the loaf] Stir - up Sunday " is past ; [people]3426-people have bought [their]3426-people raisins , and suet , and citron , and begun to mix [their]3426-people Christmas puddings . Turkeys lie dead , thick as autumn - leaves in [Vallambrosa]103-vallambrosa . The snow is gone , but not without leaving [Miss Craven]164-st. john the legacy of a very bad cold , derived from countless soaked stockings and neglected wet petticoats . [She]5258-the poor child has had it a fortnight , and [her]5258-the poor child weakened , lowered frame seems incapable of shaking off the trifling ailment . For a week [her]5258-the poor child voice has been almost gone , and [she]5258-the poor child has consumed many sticks of liquorice , many boxes of black currant lozenges , in the endeavour to bring it back to the requisite shouting pitch for the inevitable daily newspaper reading . It is afternoon : heavy rain , following the thaw , has prevented the invariable drive to [Shelford]102-shelford . [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington and [the two girls]1150-the two girls are sitting in [the great room]5279-the great room hung with battle - pieces , which is old - fashionedly named "[435-god] [the saloon]2552-the saloon . " It is a mercy that [it]5279-the great room is [a great room]5280-a great room — else the fire , piled halfway up the chimney , and the never - opened windows would render [it]5279-the great room unendurably close . As it is , the atmosphere , though less stifling than that of the interior of [the family - coach]5281-the family - coach , is fustier than is altogether agreeable . "[435-god] [[My]0-i dear]804-my dear , " says [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington , shivering , "[804-my dear] pick up [my]0-i shawl ; [I]0-i really must have sand - bags to those windows ; there comes in a wind at them that positively nearly blows one out of one 's chair . " [Esther]148-esther complies , and then resumes [her]148-esther occupation of holding a skein of wool for [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington to wind . As often as [she]5258-the poor child can do so without positive rudeness , [she]5258-the poor child takes long looks at [[her]5258-the poor child companion]3572-her companion 's face — immovably polished , like [a monumental angel]5283-a monumental angel 's : looks at [her]5258-the poor child , half out of that sheer love of beauty in any form , from [a man]3402-a man 's to a beetle 's , which is innate in some sensuous natures ; partly , and much more , because each frosty - fair feature of [her]5258-the poor child face , each trinket almost upon [her]5258-the poor child person , is linked indissolubly in [her]5258-the poor child mind with some look or word of [St. John]164-st. john . Association , [they]2554-they say , lies stronger in a smell than in aught else — stronger than in anything seen or heard ; and so now the slight subtle scent floating from [Constance]256-constance 's perfumed hair recalls to [the sad young "[804-my dear] companion]5285-the sad young " companion , " with a thrust of sharpest pain , [her]5258-the poor child one day 's betrothal ; that one day for whose sweet sake [she]5258-the poor child does not regret having endured the calamity of existence ; that day when [they]2554-they sowed — "[804-my dear] ... [Their]2554-they talk with little kisses , thickAs roses in rose harvest . " It is odd how often , when [one]559-one is musing dumbly on some unspoken name , [the people in whose company [one]559-one is]5287-the people in whose company one is give utterance to that name , without any former conversation having led up to it . "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]804-my dear [Constance]256-constance , " says [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington , [her]0-i slow old thoughts having at length travelled from draughts and sandbags , "[0-i] do [you]256-constance think [St. John]164-st. john has any fancy as to what room [he]2556-his has ? [Young men]2557-young men are sometimes faddy . [I]0-i depend upon [you]256-constance to tell [me]0-i , and [I]0-i will give [Franklin]454-franklin orders about it . " [[St. John]164-st. john 's room]5289-st. john 's room ! [He]2556-his is coming [here]3398-here , then ! The wool that [she]0-i is holding drops forgotten into [Esther]148-esther 's lap ; the old delicious carmine that used to make [her]0-i so like a dogrose springs up suddenly lovely into [her]0-i face . Love is as hard to kill as any snake : "[0-i] Now , at the last gasp of love 's latest breath , When , [his]2556-his pulse failing , passion speechless lies;When faith is kneeling by [his]2556-his bed of death , And innocence is closing up [his]2556-his eyes : Now , if [thou]2558-thou wouldst , when [all]2559-all have given [him]2556-his overFrom death to life , [thou]2558-thou mightst [him]2556-his yet recover . " "[2558-thou] Unless [you]256-constance hold the skein differently , [Miss Craven]164-st. john , [I]0-i 'm afraid [I]0-i really can not wind it , " says [Constance]256-constance , a slight shade of contemptuous displeasure in [her]0-i voice . [Esther]148-esther jumps back to reality , to find [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington 's icy , unescapable eyes riveted upon [her]148-esther . [She]148-esther can not turn away [her]148-esther head , nor dive under the table for an imaginary lost handkerchief ; [she]148-esther can not lift [her]148-esther hands to hide [her]148-esther face ; [her]148-esther occupation , which keeps both ruthlessly employed , forbids it . [She]148-esther can only sit still , plainly crimson , and be stared at . "[0-i] Thanks , very much , [aunt]1203-aunt , " [Constance]256-constance says , in [her]256-constance lady - like , piano voice , beginning again to turn the scarlet ball swiftly through [her]256-constance long pale fingers ; "[1203-aunt] but [I]0-i do n't think [he]2561-he has any fancies . " "[0-i] [The blue room]2562-the blue room , in [the west gallery]2563-the west gallery , is one of the warmest in [the house]687-the house , " rejoins [the old lady]3509-the old lady , gathering [her]3509-the old lady wraps closelier about [her]3509-the old lady : "[0-i] it is next but two to [Miss Craven]164-st. john 's ; it has the same aspect . " "[247-mr. gerard] Is [Mr. Gerard]247-mr. gerard coming here " asks [Esther]148-esther , tremulously , resolute to show [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington that [she]148-esther can mention [his]247-mr. gerard name . "[247-mr. gerard] Yes , [[my]0-i dear]804-my dear — to - morrow . Do [you]804-my dear know [him]247-mr. gerard ? Oh no ! of course [you]804-my dear can not , " replies [the old lady]3509-the old lady , looking a little inquisitively at the tender rose - face of [the girl]682-the girl . "[164-st. john] [Miss Craven]164-st. john met [him]247-mr. gerard at [Felton]44-felton , last autumn , " [Constance]256-constance answers for [her]3509-the old lady — no faintest gust of feeling apparently agitating the even indifference of [her]256-constance voice . "[247-mr. gerard] [He]247-mr. gerard was most good - natured to [her]164-st. john ; riding and walking , and altogether making a martyr of [himself]247-mr. gerard . [St. John]164-st. john makes [himself]247-mr. gerard very useful , flirting with [all the young ladies that come to [the house]687-the house]2568-all the young ladies that come to the house : [he]247-mr. gerard really is invaluable in that way ! " [Esther]148-esther stoops [her]148-esther head low down , choked with indignation . "[247-mr. gerard] Perhaps [I]0-i do n't come under the head of [a ' young lady]2570-a ' young lady , ' " [she]0-i says , almost in a whisper ; "[0-i] but [he]247-mr. gerard certainly did not flirt with [me]0-i . " "[247-mr. gerard] Did n't [he]247-mr. gerard ? " [Constance]256-constance replies , carelessly . "[247-mr. gerard] Oh , if [I]0-i recollect right , [he]247-mr. gerard amused [himself]247-mr. gerard a little — [he]247-mr. gerard always does . [I]0-i often take [him]247-mr. gerard to task about that manner of [his]247-mr. gerard ; it might give rise to unlucky mistakes ; people who do n't know [him]247-mr. gerard do n't understand it . " [Esther]148-esther bites [her]148-esther lips , but has the sense to allow , with vast difficulty , this last observation to pass unquestioned . "[247-mr. gerard] [His]247-mr. gerard horses have arrived already , " continues [Constance]256-constance , placidly ; "[247-mr. gerard] [he]247-mr. gerard has actually been unconscionable enough to send four of [them]2571-them : [he]247-mr. gerard is evidently going to test [uncle]5144-uncle 's and [your]2573-your patience to the utmost by making a perfect visitation . " "[247-mr. gerard] [Felton]44-felton is such [a good hunting country]2574-a good hunting country , that [I]0-i wonder [Mr. Gerard]247-mr. gerard can bear to leave it now , just as the frost has broken up , " remarks [Esther]148-esther , almost composedly ; a dim , exquisite hope flashing up in [her]148-esther mind that [he]247-mr. gerard has heard of [her]148-esther being at [Blessington]256-constance , and is coming to ask [her]148-esther to forgive [him]247-mr. gerard — to forgive [her]148-esther , rather ; to ask [her]148-esther to kiss and make [friends]915-friends . The story - book ending , "[247-mr. gerard] Lived happy ever after , " is running through [her]148-esther brain , when [her]148-esther reverie is broken , gently , but very effectually , as reveries are apt to be , by a simple speech of [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington 's , spoken with a little smile : "[1203-aunt] It is evident that [Miss Craven]164-st. john has not heard [our]2575-our news , is not it , [aunt]1203-aunt ? " "[164-st. john] What news ? " inquires [the girl]682-the girl , eagerly . "[1203-aunt] Nothing of much interest to [any one]523-any one but [ourselves]2575-our , [I]0-i suppose . It is only " ( speaking with slow triumph , and narrowly watching the effect of [her]0-i words ) "[164-st. john] that [St. John]164-st. john and [I]0-i have made up [our]2575-our minds to marry [one another]922-one another ! " The knife cuts as clean and clear as [she]148-esther could have wished ; the divine happy rose - flush slips away suddenly out of the poor blank face opposite [her]148-esther ; a grey ashy - white takes its place . [She]148-esther had thought that pain and pleasure were buried with [Jack]146-jack on [the slope of [Glan - yr - Afon]24-glan - yr - afon 's mountain graveyard]5296-the slope of glan - yr - afon 's mountain graveyard ; but that moment of raging agony undeceives [her]148-esther . For an instant the table and chairs seem dancing round ; a humming buzz sounds dully in [her]148-esther ears ; then the faintness passes ; the table and chairs stand still again ; the buzz ceases ; and [she]148-esther is sitting on an old gilt chair : [her]148-esther arms still moving mechanically , with the outstretched wool upon them , while [Constance]256-constance goes winding , winding on — winding away hope and pleasure and joy ; while the ball , growing larger under [her]148-esther hands , seems to have stolen its red colour from [Esther]148-esther 's heart - blood . "[2575-our] [[Our]2575-our friends]2579-our friends have really been very disagreeable to [us]2575-our about it , " says [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington with a subdued laugh ; "[2579-our friends] [they]2579-our friends tell [us]2575-our that it is the most uninteresting marriage [they]2579-our friends ever heard of , for that [they]2579-our friends had all foretold it , heaven knows how many centuries ago ! " "[2579-our friends] It is very seldom , " replies [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington , shaking [her]437-mrs. blessington head slowly to and fro , "[2579-our friends] that [a young man]2580-a young man shows the sense [St. John Gerard]455-st. john gerard has done in coming into [[his]2580-a young man parents]2581-his parents ' views for [him]2580-a young man : in the present day [they]2581-his parents are mostly so headstrong and resolute to pick and choose for [themselves]2581-his parents , which generally ends in [their]2581-his parents selecting [some worthless person utterly unsuited to [their]2581-his parents rank and fortune]2582-some worthless person utterly unsuited to their rank and fortune . " "[2583-you] How long have [you]2583-you been engaged ? " ? " Nothing ever struck [me]682-the girl as more unlikely ! "[682-the girl] " Indeed ! And why , may [I]256-constance ask ? "[256-constance] The skein is finished ; [Esther]148-esther lifts one hand to [her]148-esther face , and feels a slight relief in the partial shade . " Why , pray ? "[148-esther] with a slightly sharpened accent . " Because — because , "[148-esther] [she]148-esther answers , in confusion , " [you]2583-you had been brought up together from [children]3772-children ; because [Mr. Gerard]247-mr. gerard 's manner seemed so much more like [a brother]3525-a brother 's than [a — a — lover]5301-a — a — lover 's . "[148-esther] The word so applied half chokes [her]148-esther . " [We]5302-we dislike public demonstrations of affection , both of [us]5302-we , "[1100-the other] rejoins [the other]1100-the other , coldly displeased ; " [we]5302-we leave those to [servants]1158-servants and [savages]1763-savages . "[1100-the other] [A footman]2346-a footman enters with tea in handleless red dragon cups , costly as age , brittleness , and ingenious ugliness can make them . [Esther]148-esther leans back in [her]148-esther chair , idle , staring vacantly at the pane , blurred with big rain - drops . After a pause , " [You]148-esther have not congratulated [me]256-constance , [Miss Craven]164-st. john , "[256-constance] [Constance]256-constance says , sipping [her]256-constance tea delicately ; [her]256-constance madonna smile relaxing the severely correct lines of [her]256-constance Greek mouth . [Esther]148-esther gives a great start . " [I]148-esther ? Oh , [I]148-esther beg [your]256-constance pardon ! "[148-esther] " [I]256-constance was just going to write and tell [you]256-constance the news , "[256-constance] says [Constance]256-constance , graciously—"I thought it might interest [you]256-constance , as [you]256-constance had been with [us]2588-us so lately , and seen the whole thing going on — when [we]2588-us heard of [[your]256-constance brother]801-your brother 's sudden death . "[256-constance] [Esther]148-esther rises abruptly , and walks to the window , with that painful hatred in [her]148-esther heart towards [Miss Blessington]258-miss blessington that [we]2588-us feel towards [those who lightly name [our]2588-us sacred dead to [us]2588-us]2589-those who lightly name our sacred dead to us . " Was [he]801-your brother [[your]256-constance only brother]5306-your only brother , [[my]437-mrs. blessington dear]804-my dear ? "[437-mrs. blessington] inquires [Mrs. Blessington]437-mrs. blessington , with languid interest . " Yes . "[437-mrs. blessington] " [Dear]951-dear — dear ! Very sad — very sad ! And what did [he]801-your brother die of ? Consumption ? "[437-mrs. blessington] " No — diphtheria . "[437-mrs. blessington] " Ah ! A very fatal complaint , [[my]437-mrs. blessington dear]804-my dear , especially among [children]3772-children . [I]437-mrs. blessington have always had a great horror of it . In [my]437-mrs. blessington younger days it used to be called sore throat , but [I]437-mrs. blessington suppose it killed just as [many people]5311-many people then as it does now that it has got a fine long Latin name . [I]437-mrs. blessington suppose [[your]804-my dear poor brother]5312-your poor brother suffered a great deal — didn't [he]801-your brother , love ? "[437-mrs. blessington] No answer , except a stifled sob , a rush from [the room]3629-the room , and the sound of flying feet upon [the hall]658-the hall 's stone floor . There are some things past human endurance ; and to hear [Jack]146-jack 's parting agonies — agonies whose memory [she]437-mrs. blessington [herself]437-mrs. blessington dare as yet hardly contemplate in [her]437-mrs. blessington heart 's low depths — lightly discussed by [a gossiping old woman]2592-a gossiping old woman , is one of those things . " GET [me]148-esther some fresh candles — long ones ; longer than these — as long as [you]2592-a gossiping old woman possibly can , "[148-esther] [Esther]148-esther says that same eveing , on going to bed , to [the housemaid whom [she]148-esther finds putting coals on [her]2592-a gossiping old woman fire]2593-the housemaid whom she finds putting coals on her fire . " [I]3893-the woman think , ' m , that [you]148-esther will find these will last for to- night , "[3893-the woman] [the woman]3893-the woman answers , looking at the very respectable dimensions of the unlit candles on [Esther]148-esther 's queer old - fashioned toilet - table . " No — no , they wo n't ! "[3893-the woman] [she]3893-the woman answers , nervously ; " it is better to be on the safe side . "[3893-the woman] " Would [you]148-esther like a night - light , [miss]1911-miss ? "[3893-the woman] " Oh no , no ! they make the corners of [the room]3629-the room blacker than ever , and they cast such odd shadows . "[3893-the woman] " Not very . By - the - by "[3893-the woman] ( with a sudden inspiration ) , " have [you]148-esther got anything that [you]148-esther could give [me]3893-the woman to make [me]3893-the woman sleep — any opiate of any kind ? "[3893-the woman] " [I]3893-the woman 've got a little laudanum , [ma'am]1915-ma'am , that [Mrs. Franklin]454-franklin give [me]3893-the woman last week when [I]3893-the woman had a bad face . "[3893-the woman] " Fetch it [me]3893-the woman , "[3893-the woman] [she]3893-the woman cries , eagerly ; " that is , if [you]148-esther do n't want it [yourself]148-esther . "[3893-the woman] [The servant]800-the servant goes , and presently returns with a small dark blue bottle . " About how much ought one to take , [I]148-esther wonder ?
